<pointsOfInterest> <poi id="nile-river" name="Nile River" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/life-on-river-nile-egypt-143177176" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Africa’s longest river, the Nile, has been a lifeline since ancient times. Its waters feed crops and people, carry boats, and helped civilizations rise along its banks.</description> <originalDescription>Africa's longest river. Historically considered the world's longest river, but some research points to the Amazon being longer. The Nile is vitally important to trade, agriculture, and fishing.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="ngorongoro-crater" name="Ngorongoro Crater" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/elevated-view-floor-ngorongoro-crater-southern-1093494356" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Ngorongoro Crater is the world’s largest inactive volcanic bowl. Long ago, a giant volcano exploded and collapsed inward, leaving a crater nearly 2,000 feet deep and about 100 square miles wide.</description> <originalDescription>The world's largest inactive vocanic caldera. The crater formed when a massive volcano exploded and collapsed on itself. The crater is up to 2000 feet deep and covers nearly 100 square miles.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="okavango-delta" name="Okavango Delta" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/african-wild-dog-lycaon-pictus-pack-1064945069" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>The Okavango Delta is a vast swamp oasis teeming with life. Unusually, its waters flood during the Kalahari’s dry season, turning desert into temporary wetlands. This surprise flood draws animals to graze and hunt.</description> <originalDescription>An inland wetland home to hundreds of species of plants and animals. Uniquely, the Okavango begins flooding during the dry season of the surrounding Kalahari. This brings animals from around the Kalahari to graze and hunt.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="sahara-desert" name="Sahara Desert" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/african-man-waching-brilliant-blue-sky-1596161455" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>The Sahara is the world’s largest hot desert, an ocean of sand across North Africa. It’s sunny here nearly all the time – over 90% of daylight hours! In the blistering summer, average daytime temperatures soar above 100°F (38°C).</description> <originalDescription>The largest hot desert in the world. This massive desert spans most of North Africa. The weather is sunny over 90% of the time in most of the desert and the average temperature in the hottest months easily exceeds 100 degrees Farenheit.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="mt-kilimanjaro" name="Mt. Kilimanjaro" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/snow-on-top-mount-kilimanjaro-amboseli-181967831" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Mount Kilimanjaro is a sleeping volcano and Africa’s tallest peak. Hikers and wildlife lovers flock to its forested slopes. Even its shrinking ice cap fascinates scientists studying how fast it’s melting.</description> <originalDescription>A dormant volcano and Africa's tallest mountain.The mountain and the surrounding park are popular with hikers and wildlife lovers. Kilimanjaro's ice cap is heavily studied by scientists because it is melting quickly.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="great-rift-valley" name="Great Rift Valley" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/great-rift-valley-tanzania-340852322" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>The Great Rift Valley is a huge scar across East Africa, created as tectonic plates slowly pull the land apart. This giant valley spans from Ethiopia to Mozambique, offering breathtaking views.</description> <originalDescription>A massive and complex series of rifts formed by tectonic plates ripping the crust of East Africa apart. The Great Rift Valley forms expansive and scenic views from Ethiopia to Mozambique.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="victoria-falls" name="Victoria Falls" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/victoria-falls-zambia-zimbabwe-1049830799" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Victoria Falls is so grand, locals call it “The Smoke that Thunders.” This roaring Zambezi River waterfall is one of the largest in the world.</description> <originalDescription>In local languages, Victoria Falls is named "The smoke that thunders" and "Boiling Water". This waterfall on the Zambezi is one of the largest waterfalls on Earth.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> </pointsOfInterest> <rivers> <river>Nile</river> <river>Congo</river> <river>Niger</river> <river>Zambezi</river> <river>Orange</river> </rivers> <otherFeatures> <feature>Sahara Desert</feature> <feature>Mediterranean Sea</feature> <feature>Red Sea</feature> <feature>Nile Delta</feature> </otherFeatures> <sources> <source kind="board_poi" file="Africa Boards.xlsx" sheet="Points of Interest on Africa Ma" /> <source kind="poi_rewrites" file="Updates to Cities and points of interest.xlsx" sheet="Africa Points of Interest Rewri" /> <source kind="board_cities" file="Africa Boards.xlsx" sheet="Major African Cities and Capita" /> </sources> </poster> <poster id="cities_poi_map_asia" continent="Asia" type="cities_and_points_of_interest_map"> <title>Asia Cities & Points of Interest</title> <subtitle>Major cities, supplemental capitals, and POIs (with rewrites when available)</subtitle> <design> <iconSuggestions> <icon kind="poi" suggestion="marker" /> <icon kind="river" suggestion="line_label" /> <icon kind="capital" suggestion="star" /> <icon kind="major_city" suggestion="dot" /> </iconSuggestions> <notes> <note>Point-of-interest descriptions prefer rewrite text from the updates spreadsheet when available.</note> <note>Some source descriptions/URLs include '...' and may be truncated; validate before final production use.</note> <note>Capitals are provided as a supplement list (from 'Capitals not in column B/B' tables). image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/matterhorn-628595693" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>The Matterhorn, an iconic spire of the Alps, is roughly 50 million years old.</description> <originalDescription>Dominating the Alps range, the Matterhorn is thought to be around 50 million years old.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="the-black-forest" name="The Black Forest" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/scenic-mountain-landscape-view-on-black-1212988969" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>The Black Forest is a dense mountain woodland along Germany’s Rhine River. It’s dotted with lakes and historic towns. This peaceful region is famous for inspiring fairy tales.</description> <originalDescription>This densely wooded mountain range is situated along the Rhine River. With dozens of lakes, stunning scenery and a number of historic towns, it’s one of the most relaxing and naturally beautiful places in Germany.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="giant-s-causeway" name="Giant's Causeway" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/giants-causeway-northern-ireland-215093251" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Giant’s Causeway in Northern Ireland is a bizarre landscape of thousands of hexagonal basalt columns. These stone pillars formed long ago as cooling lava cracked into a honeycomb pattern. According to legend, an Irish giant built this “causeway” as a bridge to Scotland.</description> <originalDescription>The Giant’s Causeway is a bizarre yet fascinating natural phenomenon. It is comprised of three modestly-sized fingers of naturally created paving. Thousands of basalt columns formed as lava cooled and contracted, fracturing with mysterious regularity to create what looks like a fiendishly complicated giant keyboard – though according to folklore, the causeway is what’s left of a bridge to Scotland built by the giant, Finn McCool.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="preikestolen" name="Preikestolen" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/norway-preikestolen-august-23-2019-crowd-2097650845" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Preikestolen (“Pulpit Rock”) in Norway is a narrow cliff-top ledge almost 2,000 feet high. Visitors feel a thrill standing at the edge and peering down at the fjord.</description> <originalDescription>The thrill of the vertical drop is palpable at Preikestolen, or "Pulpit Rock," a narrow plateau towering nearly 2,000 feet above a fjord in the south of Norway.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="verdon-gorge" name="Verdon Gorge" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/view-cliffy-rocks-verdon-gorge-lake-1187871493" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Verdon Gorge—often called France’s Grand Canyon—was carved by water over 250 million years. Ancient seas and later rivers etched this valley.</description> <originalDescription>Sometimes called the "Grand Canyon of France", this gorge has been shaped by oceans and rivers for nearly 250 million years.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="white-nights" name="White Nights" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/shutterstock/photos/415624063/display_1500/stock-photo-saint-petersburg-russia-jul-mariinsky-theatre-on-jul-in-saint-petersburg-415624063.jpg" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>In summer at high latitudes (above 60° N), the sun barely sets. This creates “white nights” of endless twilight. Many northern regions—especially Russia—celebrate these magical bright nights each year.</description> <originalDescription>In the summer, days get longer. Above 60 degrees in latitude, the sun barely sets creating a perpetual twilight. These white nights are celebrated in the summer, especially in Russia.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="ice-caves-of-iceland" name="Ice Caves of Iceland" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/man-traveler-enjoying-exotic-landmark-sitting-334335584" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>In Iceland’s Vatnajökull Glacier, visitors explore dazzling blue caves inside the ice. It’s like walking through frozen tunnels of light beneath the glacier.</description> <originalDescription>Instead of walking on a glacier, visitors to the Vatnajokull Glacier Ice Caves in Iceland can walk in luminous caves embedded in the glacier.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="northern-lights" name="Northern Lights" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/aurora-borealis-northern-lights-over-mountain-1120772963" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Charged particles from the Sun crash into Earth’s upper atmosphere near the poles, making the sky glow with the dancing colors of the aurora (the Northern Lights).</description> <originalDescription>The sun releases highly charged particles that move through space. When those particles hit the Earth's atmosphere, the collisions cause bright dancing aurorae around Earth's magnetic poles.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> </pointsOfInterest> <rivers /> <otherFeatures> <feature>asia minor</feature> <feature>athens</feature> <feature>macedonia</feature> <feature>sparta</feature> <feature>mediterranean</feature> <feature>peloponnesian peninsula</feature> <feature>tiber river</feature> <feature>rome</feature> <feature>italian peninsula</feature> <feature>alps</feature> <feature>italian alps</feature> <feature>constantinople</feature> <feature>ural mountains</feature> <feature>north european plain</feature> <feature>english channel</feature> </otherFeatures> <sources> <source kind="board_poi" file="Europe Boards.xlsx" sheet="Europe Points of Interest" /> <source kind="poi_rewrites" file="Updates to Cities and points of interest.xlsx" sheet="Europe POI rewrites" /> <source kind="board_cities" file="Europe Boards.xlsx" sheet="Major European Cities" /> </sources> </poster> <poster id="cities_poi_map_north-america" continent="North America" type="cities_and_points_of_interest_map"> <title>North America Cities & Points of Interest</title> <subtitle>Major cities, supplemental capitals, and POIs (with rewrites when available)</subtitle> <design> <iconSuggestions> <icon kind="poi" suggestion="marker" /> <icon kind="river" suggestion="line_label" /> <icon kind="capital" suggestion="star" /> <icon kind="major_city" suggestion="dot" /> </iconSuggestions> <notes> <note>Point-of-interest descriptions prefer rewrite text from the updates spreadsheet when available.</note> <note>Some source descriptions/URLs include '...' and may be truncated; validate before final production use.</note> <note>Capitals are provided as a supplement list (from 'Capitals not in column B/B' tables). image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/aerial-shot-amazon-rainforest-brazil-south-408722248" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Spanning 9 countries, the Amazon is Earth’s marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/view-two-beaches-on-bartolome-island-265791809" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>The Galápagos Islands, ~600 miles off Ecuador’s coast, are famous for unique creatures found nowhere else. Observations here helped Charles Darwin develop his theory of evolution.</description> <originalDescription>This archipelago 600 miles off the coast of Ecuador is famous for its high number of endemic species and its influence on Darwin’s theory of evolution by natural selection.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="lake-titicaca" name="Lake Titicaca" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/uros-floating-island-near-puno-city-1182193597" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Lake Titicaca is the world’s highest navigable lake and the largest in South America. It's numerous islands are home to several unique cultures.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="atacama-desert" name="Atacama Desert" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/moon-valley-valle-de-la-luna-1063067663" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>The Atacama Desert is the driest place on Earth outside the poles. Its landscape of volcanoes, geysers, hot springs, and jagged hills looks so otherworldly that movies often film here to mimic Mars.</description> <originalDescription>The driest non-polar desert in the world features volcanoes, geysers, hot springs, and jagged hills that look like an alien planet. A lot of films and TV series use the Atacama as a stand-in for Mars.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="torres-del-paine" name="Torres del Paine" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/majestic-mountain-landscape-reflection-mountains-lake-380179537" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Torres del Paine is famous for jagged mountain peaks ringed by rivers, glaciers, and lakes.</description> <originalDescription>A breathtaking national park famous for its jagged mountains surrounded by rivers, glaciers, and lakes.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="uyuni-salt-flats" name="Uyuni Salt Flats" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/worlds-largest-salt-flat-salar-de-317843843" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Bolivia’s Uyuni Salt Flats cover nearly 4,100 square miles. They are so flat that their height varies by less than a meter across the whole area. In some places the salt crust is several meters thick. Amazingly, over half of Earth’s known lithium lies beneath these flats.</description> <originalDescription>The Uyuni Salt flats span nearly 4100 square miles, and are so flat that their elevation only varies by less than a meter. The salty crust is up several meters deep in some places. Also, these salt flats are home to over half of the Earth's known lithium reserves.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="perito-moreno-glacier" name="Perito Moreno Glacier" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/perito-moreno-glacier-located-los-glaciares-770757355" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Perito Moreno Glacier in Argentina sits in the Southern Patagonian Ice Field—the world’s third-largest reserve of fresh water. Unlike most glaciers, this one hasn’t been shrinking despite rising global temperatures.</description> <originalDescription>Located in the the Southern Patagonian Ice Field, which is the third largest reserve of fresh water. At its entrance, sheer rock cliffs soar ~3,900 feet high, framing the dark waters below.</description> <originalDescription>Milford Sound is the leading natural attraction within the country of New Zealand. The sound runs 9.3 miles inland from the Tasman Sea. The mouth of the fjord is engulfed by rock faces that tower into the sky of the fjord reaching height of 3,900 feet.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> </pointsOfInterest> <rivers /> <otherFeatures /> <sources> <source kind="board_poi" file="Australia slash Oceania Boards.xlsx" sheet="Oceania Points of Interest" /> <source kind="poi_rewrites" file="Updates to Cities and points of interest.xlsx" sheet="OCeania poi updates" /> <source kind="board_cities" file="Australia slash Oceania Boards.xlsx" sheet="Major Oceanian Cities" /> </sources> </poster> <poster id="cities_poi_map_antarctica" continent="Antarctica" type="cities_and_points_of_interest_map"> <title>Antarctica Cities & Points of Interest</title> <subtitle>Major cities, supplemental capitals, and POIs (with rewrites when available)</subtitle> <design> <iconSuggestions> <icon kind="poi" suggestion="marker" /> <icon kind="river" suggestion="line_label" /> <icon kind="capital" suggestion="star" /> <icon kind="major_city" suggestion="dot" /> </iconSuggestions> <notes> <note>Point-of-interest descriptions prefer rewrite text from the updates spreadsheet when available.</note> <note>Some source descriptions/URLs include '...' and may be truncated; validate before final production use.</note> <note>Capitals are provided as a supplement list (from 'Capitals not in column B/B' tables). If you need a complete capitals list or a capital/non-capital flag for every major city, add that as a separate data layer.</note> </notes> </design> <majorCities /> <capitalsSupplement /> <pointsOfInterest> <poi id="mount-erebus" name="Mount Erebus" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/mount-erebus-antarctica-panoramic-composite-1277368948" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Earth’s southernmost fire-mountain, glowing nonstop since 1841.</description> <originalDescription>This large Antarctic volcano has erupted continuously since 1841.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="airdevronsix-icefall" name="Airdevronsix Icefall" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/12/Airdevronsix_Icefalls_2016.jpg" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Ice cliffs named after Navy Squadron Six spill a white waterfall of glacier into the bone-dry McMurdo Valleys.</description> <originalDescription>Named for U.S. Navy Air Development Squadron Six, these icefalls are larger than any waterfall on Earth. The East Antarctic Ice sheet pours from the hills above into the dry valleys below.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="blood-falls" name="Blood Falls" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f5/Blood_Falls_by_Peter_Rejcek.jpg" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Rust-red water oozes from Taylor Glacier, iron-rich and bacteria-fed, painting the ice like a frozen lava flow.</description> <originalDescription>The reddish orange color of this waterfall comes from iron trapped underneath the glacier. Iron that is slowly being eaten by rare bacteria.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="katabatic-winds" name="Katabatic Winds" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" missing_image="true"> <description>Super-cold, heavy air races downhill at near-hurricane speeds—a gravity-powered chill sweeping Antarctica’s glaciers clean.</description> <originalDescription>Hot air rises. But the katabatic winds are so cold and dense that they can move down glaciers at near hurricane speed.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="lake-vanda" name="Lake Vanda" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-baGxgvU_U-A/WUcCE5VUtbI/AAAAAAAAoQM/6MDgbAloArYX-j4KPQrp-OrUDtx2PozHQCLcBGAs/s1600/hypersaline%2Blake%2BVanda.jpg" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Ten-times saltier than seawater, Lake Vanda stays liquid under ice, stacking warm layers like a natural solar pool.</description> <originalDescription>The water in Lake Vanda is 10 times saltier than sea water. It's even saltier than the Dead Sea.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="cape-renard" name="Cape Renard" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/extensive-icy-tidewater-glaciers-meet-ocean-1759329167" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Jagged Una Peaks spear skyward at Cape Renard, an 1898 discovery guiding ships through Antarctic fjords.</description> <originalDescription>Known for the distinct rock outcroppings known as the Una Peaks, Cape Renard was discovered in 1898.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="deception-island" name="Deception Island" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://www.shutterstock.com/image-photo/rare-aerial-footage-deception-island-antarctica-665803489" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Sail into a hidden volcano: Deception Island’s caldera harbor steams with geothermal beaches amid South Shetland’s icy seas.</description> <originalDescription>Part of the South Shetland Islands, Deception Island is the exposed part of an active shield volcano with a diameter of 30 km.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> <poi id="lake-untersee" name="Lake Untersee" marker_kind="point_of_interest" default_icon="marker" image_url="https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c9/Untersee_%28Wohlthatmassiv%29.jpg" image_url_is_truncated="false"> <description>Sealed beneath ice lids, Lake Untersee brews “alien” life—ultra-alkaline, oxygen-rich waters where microbes belch methane bubbles like champagne.</description> <originalDescription>This permanently frozen freshwater lake has a pH that peaks at 12.1. Unique microorganisms and certain sediments keep the pH high, supersaturate the lake with oxygen, and produce extreme amounts of methane.</originalDescription> <originalDescriptionIsTruncated>false</originalDescriptionIsTruncated> </poi> </pointsOfInterest> <rivers /> <otherFeatures /> <sources> <source kind="board_poi" file="Antarctica Boards.xlsx" sheet="Antarctica Points of Interest" /> <source kind="poi_rewrites" file="Updates to Cities and points of interest.xlsx" sheet="Antarctic rewrites" /> </sources> </poster> </posters> </bundle>
